Office of Secretary of State, Lincoln. Nebraska, November 30, 1908. To His Excellency, George Lawson Sheldon, Governor of the State of Nebraska: IDear Sir: I have the honor to present herewith my biennial report as See - y of State, for the biennium ending November 30, 1908, which contain* a ment of all fees received by this office. BThis report contains appropriations for, and the expenditures of this office, list of corporations filing articles during the last biennium. I The report of municipal and school bonds approved by me is omitted, as the ! appears in the report of the Auditor of Public Accounts. I have also omitted of approval of banks, as this list appears in the report of the Banking d. List of notary commissions issued has also been omitted. The contracts i and entered into by the Board of Public Lands 4 Buildings for repairs and ovements at the several State Institutions 1 have also omitted, together with :ontracts for fuel and supplies, as the same will appear in the report of the missioner of Public Lands & Buildings. ■ In this report 1 have endeavored to include only such matters as pertain to office, Respectfully submitted, Geo. C. Jinkin.

LEGISLATIVE RECOMMENDATIONS Corporations There are now recorded in this Department al>out nine thousand Articles of Incorporation, and Amendments. These filings date back la the beginning of the State, and there is no doubt but what of this nine thousand there are probably five thousand not doing business at the present time, having closed up their affairs and retired. In keeping up our records and answering inquiries, and they are numerous both from our own and other - is. necessary for us to go over all of these many tilings and it is becoming very burdensome I would recom - mend that the Legislature means whereby the filing of all Corpor - ations that are not in existence and doing business be cancelled upon our records. I find that most of the other States have an annual license fee for Corporations. This fee is very small, ranging from $2.00 to $20.00, in which they provide that when a Corporation fails to pay this annual license steps may be taken to have its filings cancelled. This method seems to us to be one that would meet the re - quirements and not be a burden upon the Corporation. This license should in - clude both Domestic and Foreign Corporations, and no Foreign Corporation should be allowed to do business within this State, which Li organized under the laws of another State, whose law is not as restrictive as our own.

Since that time the iiiiiiiIkt has increased m ?nt there are over 4,200 automobile- he law pro pay an annual license of $1.00 it is l>ecoming quite a revenue to the - it is also a great deal of extra work upon this Department. ;. mij month to notify the owners who fail to apply for their annual lie Blue Book I wftuld recommend that an appropriation be made for the publi il commonly called ■The Blue Book," one in which the will appear, and such other matters as will interest those making a st'. public affairs. Almost every other State prepares such a lx>ok and semi-, a copy to this Department with a request for exchange, and we have calls from a great many libraries and Public Institut le of Nebraska for a record of this kind. This book could be prepared under the direction of the Secretary Printing Board with but 1 it tl« ,te outside of the pu MM. Primary Election Law We would recommend that the Primary Election Law be so amended aa to give this Department more time between the last day of filing of candidates and the date for getting the certificates into the hands of the County Clerks. I'nder the pre.'ent law there is practically no time allowed between the last day for re - ceiving the filings and the date we are expected to have the certificates in the

16 hand* of the County Clerks. It takes from two to three days for the prim get these certificates off the press after we have supplied them with the copy Extra Clerk Hire This Department during the last biennium, or more definitely speaking, that part of the biennium commencing April 1st. 1907. has not been conducted with - out being compelled to hire extra help. The legislature of 1907 passed a number I carrying out of which fell upon this Department, one of the ■Mat < >f which was the Primary Klection Law. This law places upon thia Department a far greater amount of work than the general election law and I would recommend that in I riat ion for this office there be a liberal amount allowed for the hiring of tfcif extra help, for if such is not done it will Ik- impossible; for us to give good and prompt serivce to the |>eople. I would n spect fully urge the Board on abort matter for the i : we mill be unable to run these boilers longer than spring without the repar I ask Engineer State House REPORT OF THE STATE PRINTING BOARD During the biennium of 1907 -ON the State Printing Board has secured bids upon and awarded contracts for many hundreds of dollars' worth of miscellaneous printing and stationery supplies for the different departments and institutions operating under the state government. While the volume of this business makes it impractical to submit here a detailed statement thereof, the records of the board give tangible and indisputable proof that the numerous small items have bean purchased by this method at a net reduction in cost of from 25 to 50 per cent, as compared with the prices customarily paid previous to the adoption of the present system ■For each letting a tabulated schedule is prepared, giving full infom rding items, bidders, prices and awards, the same being preserved as a p. ie records of this board. |a> Throughout the biennium competition has lieen keen, with the result that, 'listanding the hea I labor and material, the state has secured full value for the money expended for printing The number of K<\-|«H't fully sul>mitU'<i. v. <; s\wvtK
